#Text=Montreal
#Text=Montreal
#Text=( French : Montréal ) is the largest city in the Canadian province of Quebec .
#Text=While Quebec
#Text=City is the capital , Montreal is the cultural and economic centre , and the main entry point to the province .
#Text=With 1.7 million citizens in the city and 4 million in the urban area , Montreal is Canada 's second largest city , and the largest francophone city in the Americas .
#Text=Montreal is the second-largest French-speaking ( as a mother language ) city in the world , behind Paris .
#Text=Still , around 12 % of the population speak English as a mother language , and most Francophones are conversant in English to varying degrees of fluency .
#Text=Old Montreal
#Text=has a heritage of colonial times .
#Text=Though a large city , Montreal gives opportunities for outdoor life , and for watching the legendary Montréal Canadiens ice hockey team .
#Text=Ville-Marie borough
#Text=Neighbourhoods from west to east :
#Text=Understand
#Text=On an island in the St. Lawrence River at the historically highest navigable point , Montreal has been a strategic location since before the arrival of Europeans in Canada .
#Text=A thriving Iroquoian town called Hochelaga was on the site of present-day Montreal when explorer Jacques Cartier first visited in 1535 .
#Text=In 1642 , the tiny town of Ville-Marie was founded as a Catholic mission by Paul Chomedey , sieur de Maisonneuve .
#Text=It soon became a centre of the fur trade .
#Text=After its capture by the English in 1762 , Montreal remained ( until the 1970s ) the most important city in Canada and was briefly capital of the province in the 1840s .
#Text=Prohibition on sales of alcohol in the United States during the 1920s and 1930s made Montreal a Mecca for cross-border fun seekers from nearby New England and New York .
#Text=The city built up a seedy , yet playful , industry in alcohol , burlesque , and other vices .
#Text=In the 1960s , an urban renewal drive centred on Expo 67 .
#Text=The World 's Fair in Montreal brought a subway system ( the métro ) and attractive urban parks and is considered to be one of the most successful World Fairs .
#Text=Over 50 million visitors gathered in Montreal during this memorable summer .
#Text=The 1976 Olympics left a strikingly idiosyncratic stadium and many other urban improvements .
#Text=The opening of the Saint Lawrence Seaway in 1959 , though much-lauded as an economic boom , spelled the beginning of the end for Montreal 's economic dominance in Canada .

#Text=Once the transition point between western railways and eastern sea carriers , Montreal watched helplessly as some of this business moved farther west , up the now navigable seaway , to ports in Ontario and on Lake Superior .
#Text=The Quebec sovereignty movement , which began to pick up steam in the 1960s , further chilled the atmosphere for Canada-wide businesses , many of which moved their headquarters to Toronto .
#Text=Following an economic depression in the 1980s and 1990s , Montreal became more secure in its place in North America and the world .
#Text=It remains a centre of culture , arts , computer technology , aerospace , the biotech industry , and media for all of Canada .
#Text=Orientation
#Text=It has been said that Montréal is the only city in the world where the sun " rises in the south "
#Text=.
#Text=Montrealers use an unconventional compass , using the river and the mountain as cardinal points .
#Text=When you are downtown , the St Lawrence River is “ south ” and Mount Royal is “ north ” ; making the West Island and the East End correct in both their names and orientations .
#Text=This tends to confuse visitors because the “ East ”
#Text=End is really north and the “ South ”
#Text=Shore is east , and the St Lawrence River runs almost north-south at this location .
#Text=Most local maps use this convention as do the highways around the city .
#Text=For example , Autoroute 15 north actually runs northwest and Autoroute 40 east runs northeast .
#Text=To underscore this fact , a Montreal map will show that the " south end " of Victoria Bridge is in fact further north than the " north end " .
#Text=Gay Montreal
#Text=Montreal is an extremely inviting destination for gay and lesbian tourists .

#Text=Canada 's contributions to gay rights have become widely known , but Quebec was the first province in Canada to pass a non-discrimination law for sexual orientation and to provide same-sex civil unions ( although Toronto was the first municipality in Canada to do so ) .

#Text=Same-sex marriage is legal in Quebec ( neither residency nor citizenship are required for a marriage licence , but there is a three-week waiting period after you receive the licence ) as it is in the rest of Canada .
#Text=Canadian and Quebec immigration law allow residents to sponsor their same-sex partners or spouses .
#Text=Montreal is a very safe , open , and inviting city .
#Text=The métro station in the Gay Village , Beaudry , is marked with rainbow pillars .
#Text=Divers/Cité Montreal 's pride celebration
#Text=( last week of July , first week of August ) is the second-largest in Canada after Toronto ' s.
#Text=Climate
#Text=The climate of Montreal is a true humid continental climate with 4 distinct seasons .
#Text=The city has warm — and occasionally hot & humid — summers , generally mild spring and autumn , and often very cold & snowy winters .
#Text=Montreal gets over 2,000 hours of sunshine annually .
#Text=Precipitation is moderate throughout the year , with around 2 metres of snow per season .
#Text=Visitor information
#Text=Centre Infotouriste de Montréal
#Text=, 1255 rue Peel , bureau 100 ( At rue Sainte-Catherine ; metro Peel ) , ☏ +1514 873-2015 , toll-free : +1-877-266-5687 , ✉ info@bonjourquebec.com .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Montreal 's ( YUL ) ( also known to locals as Dorval Airport ) is west of the city centre on Expressway ( Autoroute ) 20 .
#Text=Travel time to the airport from the city centre can be as much as an hour , depending on traffic .
#Text=The airport is served by all major Canadian and U.S. airlines and is a major hub for Air Canada , Air Transat , and WestJet .
#Text=There are daily trans-Atlantic flights to and from ( among others ) London , Amsterdam , Paris , Geneva , Zurich , Athens , Doha , Frankfurt , Rome , Madrid , Lisbon , Munich , and Casablanca .
#Text=Trans-Pacific flights are more limited but growing .
#Text=Air China has service to Beijing , and Air Canada offers services to Shanghai and Tokyo .

#Text=The taxi fare to and from downtown is a fixed price of $ 40 ( a sticker on the window behind the driver gives the boundaries of the zone where the flat fare applies ; if you are going from or to places outside this zone , you will have to pay a metered fare with a minimum rate of $ 17 ) .
#Text=STM Airport Express bus 747
#Text=offers service between the airport and Montreal 24 hours a day .
#Text=A single fare will cost $ 10 ( exact change in coins only when paid in the bus ) and includes unlimited use of the STM bus and metro network for the following 24 hours .
#Text=There 's a machine that takes credit cards inside the arrivals area where you can purchase fares ( including a three-day pass for $ 18 ) .
#Text=To get to the bus stop leave the arrivals area and go to the right .
#Text=There is an area to line up for the 747 buses .
#Text=The bus will stop at Lionel-Groulx metro station , and some buses continue to various downtown stops ( the bus 's marquee will state which ) .
#Text=It is possible to go downtown by the cheaper regular public transit system .

#Text=Late at night , it is all right , but during peak hours , you will need to complete several transfers with potentially crowded vehicles , so it is really only best to do so only if you are on a very low budget and/or have very light baggage .
#Text=Between 05:00 and 01:00 , take STM bus 204 east ( est ) which leaves from outside arrivals every 30 min to Gare Dorval ( Dorval Train Station ) .
#Text=Check that the driver is not going west ( ouest ) as both ways are served from almost the same place , and the sign does not say .
#Text=You can also use the 209 on weekdays to get to Gare Dorval .
#Text=Also , be sure to keep the ticket that the driver will give you as it is a transfer which you will need later .
#Text=From Gare Dorval , use your transfer ticket to catch any one of buses 211 , 411 , 405 , 425 , or 485 to Lionel-Groulx metro station .
#Text=Also make sure it is going east as the same routes go west too .
#Text=Your transfer will then let you into the metro .
#Text=Take the Montmorency-bound orange line or the Honoré-Beaugrand-bound green line into downtown on the metro .
#Text=This costs only $ 3.25 , but exact change in coins only must be provided to the first driver .

#Text=Between 05:00 and 01:00 , for the same price ( $ 3.25 , exact change in coins only ) , take bus 356 ( again , check that the driver is going east , not west ) directly into downtown via Sherbrooke .
#Text=This bus runs relatively close to most downtown hotels .
#Text=However , if needed , a transfer can be completed to access the rest of the city .
#Text=See the STM 's trip planner or Google Maps for more details .

#Text=At Gare Dorval it is also possible to catch the Exo commuter rail to downtown ( Direction Lucien L'Allier ) , during the day from 06:00 to 20:00 for a single one-way fare of $ 6 , leading to the downtown station of Lucien L'Allier which is also atop the Lucien L'Allier metro station .
#Text=Plattsburgh International Airport
#Text=and Burlington International Airport , in the United States , are 1 hr 20 min and 1 hr 50 min , respectively , by car from Montreal .
#Text=Adirondack Trailways offers a bus service between Plattsburgh International Airport and Montreal .
#Text=Greyhound offers a bus service from Burlington International Airport and Montreal .

#Text=For travellers from the US , these airports may offer a significant cost savings compared to Trudeau but at the added inconvenience of arranging ground transportation between the US and Canada .
